PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION
(Remuneration of Chairman and Members)


2.52 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, I rise to move the motion standing in my name as it appears in item 2 of the Order Paper.*
*That this Assembly, pursuant to subsection (1) of section 79 of the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958, resolves that the remuneration of the Chairman and Members of the Public Service Commission established under section 76 of the aforementioned Order shall be as follows:-

    (a) for the Chairman, an inclusive salary of $2,000 per month;

    (b) for the Deputy Chairman, a retainer of $750 per month and in addition, $30 per day on which he attends a meeting of the Commission with a maximum of 20 days in any one month; and

    (c) for other Members, a retainer of $500 per month and in addition, $30 per day on which they attend a meeting of the Commission with a maximum of 20 days in any one month.


    Members of the Assembly will know that under section 79 (2) of the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958, the terms of service of Members

Column: 385

of the Public Service Commission shall either -

    be prescribed by or under any law made under this Order; or

    (in so far as they are not prescribed by or under any such law) be prescribed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara.

Further, section 79 subsection (3)-

    The terms of service of any member shall not be altered to his disadvantage during his continuance in office.

    In keeping with the salary structure of the Government service, we have allowed a provision of $2,000 per month for the Chairman, $750 for the Deputy Chairman, and $500 for the three other Members of the Commission. In arriving at the sum of $2,000, we took into consideration the fact that the predecessor of the office had a total emolument of $2,300.

    I think Members of the Assembly remember what happened to the variable allowances. And pan passu with these cuts in variable allowances, the salary of the Chairman of the Public Service Commission is now fixed at $2,000 per month. As for the Deputy Chairman and other Members, they have remained as before - at $750 and $500 - the only alteration being the drop in the allowance from $50 per meeting to $30 per meeting.

    Sir, I beg to move.

FACTORIES (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Ordered for Second Reading read.

Column: 388



3.03 p.m.

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Factories Ordinance provides for the regulation and supervision of health, safety and welfare of persons employed in factories and other workplaces. An amendment to section 6, subsection (4) of this Ordinance is now considered necessary to provide that small factories employing less than ten persons will only be exempted from the provisions of the Ordinance if no mechanical power, steam boiler, steam container, steam receiver, cast iron underfired vulcaniser, air receiver, refrigerating plant pressure receiver, or gas plant is used, or where no highly inflammable or noxious substance is manipulated, used or created.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Ordinance stands, no legal action can be taken against a small factory employing less than ten persons even though it uses the kind of machinery mentioned above. It has been found that there are a large number of factories having less than ten persons using out-of-date machinery which did not originally have safety guards incorporated, or where they have had safety guards, these could easily be removed, Sir.

    The Government is merely seeking power to take preventive action against serious accidents to life and limb in small factories employing less than ten persons where dangerous machinery of the type mentioned above is used, and which are now excluded from the Factories Ordinance, Sir.

    In a recent case, a locally assembled grinding machine burst its grinding wheel, a piece of which hit the operator in the face, killing him instantly.

    The present amendment to the Factories Ordinance is designed to enable proper control to be exercised in respect of such activities where dangerous machinery is used in small factories employing less than ten persons.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, you will remember that the original Factories Bill provided that premises in which there were less

Column: 389

than six employees should be exempted from the provisions of the Ordinance. This Bill was later referred to a Select Committee of the House, and was discussed in Select Committee on the 15th September, 1958. It was first proposed to the Select Committee that the exemption should be extended to premises in which there were less than 16 employees, and the Chief Minister, Tun Lim Yew Hock, agreed to a compromise by which premises with less than ten employees were to be exempted from the provisions of the Factories Ordinance. It was thought that such an exemption would make it unnecessary for a lot of small businesses to comply with the onerous provisions of the Ordinance.

    There was a lot of confusion of thought as to what the Bill was designed to do when it was last before this House. Members who spoke in the Select Committee mentioned that great hardship would be caused to small businesses, in which no machinery was used, if they were not exempted from the provisions of the Ordinance. I would refer you, Mr Speaker, to the proceedings of the 15th September, 1958, in Select Committee, and I will quote extracts from speeches which were made by hon. Members at that time.

    This is what one hon. Member had to say:

    This Bill is bringing in, for the first time, certain trades within the definition of "factory", trades which do not use any mechanical devices or machinery.'

    In fact, all factories use mechanical devices or machinery, Sir. For instance, this is what the same Member said:

    "The shoe makers and garment manufacturers have, on analysis, more than six workers in their premises. With the trades which are not using any mechanical or electrical machinery, what is important are the conditions of work from the health point of view of the workers, and I do not think the original intention of this Bill was to bring these trades within its provisions. Consequently, I think an increase to the number would automatically exempt most of these trades from the provisions of the Bill."

    It was not realised at the time that premises using the type of machinery mentioned in the Ordinance would be just as dangerous to safety even if a

Column: 390

single workman was employed to tend the machinery. I have just mentioned the case of the grinding machine which burst its grinding wheel, and which instantaneously killed the person operating it. It is therefore considered essential that factories employing less than ten persons and which are operated by mechanical power or which use highly inflammable, or noxious substances should also be brought under the provisions of the Factories Ordinance for the reasons which I have stated above. I do move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This is a short and simple Bill, the urgency of which is due to the fact that the life of the current Hotels Licensing Board expired on 10th August, 1959, and new appointments are necessary. In accordance with the provisions of the existing section 3 of the Hotels Ordinance, 1959, this Board consisted of a Chairman appointed by the Governor in Council and not less than six members elected by the Justices of the Peace from among themselves and appointed by the Governor in Council.

    The new Government considers, however, that in view of the new constitutional changes, it would now be more appropriate for the Minister to appoint the Chairman and members of the Board.

CITY COUNCIL (INVALIDATION OF PROCEEDINGS) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.17 p.m.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Ong Eng Guan): Mr Speaker, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The main purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the invalidation of certain acts and proceedings of the so-called Tang Peng Yeu-Vasagar City Council in the six weeks between 18th April, 1959 and 5th June, 1959. The people know that during this short period of six weeks, many acts and decisions were passed by this rump City Council depleted of any mandate or any authority to carry on. It made important decisions which affected the interests of the nation for a long time, in some cases raising fundamental issues.

    A case in point is the question of tariff charges for electricity supplied to cinemas. Mr Speaker, during the ten years

Column: 392

when the Member for Farrer Park was in sole charge of the City Council, we the people of Singapore had to pay 20 cents a unit for electricity charges while cinema-owners had to pay only three to four cents a unit for their lighting. That had been going on for nearly ten years until we found it out. The case they put up was to masquerade under the so-called maximum demand tariff that, without these cinemas, the electricity being churned out from the Pasir Panjang Power Station would be thrown into the sea. We know that this was far from true. We raised the cinema rates from three or four cents to 20 cents per Unit. But during the six weeks that the watch-dogs of the nation were not in the Council, the rump City Council of Tang Peng Yeu Vasagar rescinded our decision and decided to conclude an agreement with the cinema-owners providing for a substantial reduction in the rates payable.

    Mr Speaker, I have in front of me a so-called agreement signed between the parties. This deed of compromise was made on the 29th day of May, 1959. There are a few significant features in this agreement. One was that although it was purported to be the 29th of May, 1959, and even if the accepted date is truly the 29th day of May, the stamp is on the 1st of June, 1959. The fact is that the 29th of May, 1959, is a date which we call the eve of a beautiful funeral. Because on the 30th, the electorate condemned the Parties whose representatives had signed this agreement.

    The second significant feature in this agreement was that in the more than 100 years of Municipal history, as I have been told, never had an agreement been concluded on duplicating paper. All agreements were printed and properly sealed. That was the first time in Municipal history that a very important document had been stencilled on cheap printing paper, and with many typing mistakes.

    Mr Speaker, just to give an instance of the typing mistakes. This deed of compromise made between the City Council of the one part, and the companies and persons - 25 in number - of the other part; the "25" was changed in handwriting to "17". Apparently eight of them

Column: 393

might have had cold feet, knowing very well that when we came in we would rescind it.

    Mr Speaker, on the 19th of April, 1959, the Chairman of my Party made this important announcement. This is contained in the Straits Times of the 19th April, 1959:

    'Dr Toh also warned that the C.A.O. and the Minister for Local Government, Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat, would be held personally responsible "for any acts committed in this interregnum which is detrimental to the public interest.

    The next Government will rescind and reverse any decision or action which is not in the people's interest,".'

    Mr Speaker, we gave due warning to all persons concerned who had dealings with this rump City Council that their actions could be re-opened and subject to review. And we have here eight enlightened cinema-owners who understood that this document was a document which was going to be perpetrated against the interests of the country. They thus refused to sign and, as a result, the "25" had been corrected in pencil to "17". There are also the initials of Mr P. C. Marcus as the C.A.O., Mr G. B. Armstrong, as a City Councillor, and one member representing the theatre and cinema-owners who initialled just behind the pencil mark.

    Mr Speaker, this Bill seeks to rectify, by legislation, this most unsatisfactory situation, by giving powers to the Minister to invalidate any act or proceedings of this rump City Council which is not considered to be in the public interest, and also to render null and void all contracts and agreements entered into on the authority of such acts and proceedings. The people pay 20 cents per unit for electricity. The cinema-owners should not pay only six cents.

    Mr Speaker, provision has also been made in the Bill for compensation to be awarded in cases where hardships may arise as a result of the invalidation action taken. I wish to make some explanation on this. There has been a contract on certain sewerage works of the City Council. The lowest tenderer withdrew for no reason whatsoever. In the normal practice in the City Council, they always

Column: 394

re-tender. But in this case, the Committee, consisting of the residual of the rump City Council, decided to give it to the second lowest tenderer and it cost a quarter of a million dollars more. After we had been elected in as the new Government, I received certain letters explaining to me why the first tenderer withdrew and the reasons which they considered motivated the giving of the tender to the second lowest tenderer. This action was against all previous precedents. Mr Speaker, we have taken action on this. We have frozen the contract - luckily the contract was not signed yet. We were fast enough to take action and, although the contract was not signed, the second lowest tenderer had done some spade-work and perhaps, in such cases, it might be necessary to pay a little bit of compensation to the contractor, although it was not the fault of the City Council that he had proceeded with the work.

    Now, Mr Speaker, there are many more instances of actions taken by this rump City Council which are against the interests of the country and which have to be invalidated. This Bill will provide for such powers.

    Mr Speaker, I beg to move.
